DOCNAME: CASE OF GOLDER v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . In DATE , Mr. PERSON , a GPE citizen born in DATE , was convicted in GPE of robbery with violence and was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . In DATE , PERSON was serving his sentence in FAC on LOC .
CARDINAL . On TIME of CARDINAL DATE , a serious disturbance occurred in a recreation area of the prison where PERSON happened to be .

On DATE , a prison officer , Mr. PERSON , who had taken part and been injured in quelling the disturbance , made a statement identifying his assailants , in the course of which he declared : " PERSON was screaming ... and PERSON , PERSON and another prisoner whom I know by sight , I think his name is PERSON ... were swinging vicious blows at me . "

CARDINAL . On DATE , together with other prisoners suspected of having participated in the disturbance , was segregated from the main body of prisoners . On CARDINAL and DATE , PERSON was interviewed by police officers . At the second of these interviews he was informed that it had been alleged that he had assaulted a prison officer ; he was warned that " the facts would be reported in order that consideration could be given whether or not he would be prosecuted for assaulting a prison officer causing bodily harm " .

CARDINAL . PERSON wrote to his Member of ORG on DATE and DATE , and to a Chief Constable on DATE , about the disturbance of DATE and the ensuing hardships it had entailed for him ; the prison governor stopped these letters since PERSON had failed to raise the subject - matter thereof through the authorised channels beforehand .
CARDINAL . In a second statement , made on DATE , PERSON qualified as follows what he had said earlier :
" When I mentioned the prisoner PERSON , I said ‘ I think it was Golder’ , who was present with PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , when the CARDINAL latter were attacking me .
" If it was PERSON and I certainly remember seeing him in the immediate group who were screaming abuse and generally making a nuisance of themselves , I am not certain that he made an attack on me .

" Later when PERSON and PERSON grabbed me , PERSON was also present but I can not remember who the other inmate was , but there were several there one of whom stood out in particular but I can not put a name to him . "
On DATE , another prison officer reported that :
" ... during the riot of that night I spent the majority of the time in the T.V. room with the prisoners who were not participating in the disturbance .
DATE , PERSON was in this room with me and to the best of my knowledge took no part in the riot .
His presence with me can be borne out by officer ... who observed us both from the outside . "
PERSON was returned to his ordinary cell DATE .

lCARDINAL . Meanwhile , the prison authorities had been considering the various statements , and on DATE prepared a list of charges which might be preferred against prisoners , including PERSON , for offences against prison discipline . Entries relating thereto were made in PERSON ’s prison record . No such charge was eventually preferred against him and the entries in his prison record were marked " charges not proceeded with " . Those entries were expunged from the prison record in DATE during the examination of the applicant ’s case by ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE , PERSON addressed a petition to the Secretary of ORG for ORG , that is , the ORG Secretary . He requested a transfer to some other prison and added :

" I understand that a statement wrongly accusing me of participation in the events of DATE , made by Officer PERSON , is lodged in my prison record . I suspect that it is this wrong statement that has recently prevented my being recommended by the local parole board for parole .

" I would respectfully request permission to consult a solicitor with a view to taking civil action for libel in respect of this statement .... Alternatively , I would request that an independent examination of my record be allowed by Mrs. PERSON who is magistrate . I would accept her assurance that this statement is not part of my record and be willing to accept then that the libel against me has not materially harmed me except for DATE I spent in the separate cells and so civil action would not be then necessary , providing that an apology was given to me for the libel .... "
CARDINAL . In GPE the matter of contacts of convicted prisoners with persons outside their place of detention is governed by LAW , as amended and subordinate legislation made under LAW .

Section CARDINAL , sub - section I , of FAC provides that " the Secretary of ORG may make rules for the regulation and management of prisoners ... and for the ... treatment ... discipline and control of persons required to be detained .... "

The rules made by the Home Secretary in the exercise of this power are the Prison Rules DATE , which were laid before ORG and have the status of a ORG . The relevant provisions concerning communications between prisoners and persons outside prison are contained in Rules DATE and DATE as follows :
" Letters and visits generally
Rule CARDINAL

( CARDINAL ) The Secretary of ORG may , with a view to securing discipline and good order or the prevention of crime in the interests of any persons , impose restrictions , either generally or in a particular case , upon the communications to be permitted between a prisoner and other persons .

( CARDINAL ) Except as provided by statute or these Rules , a prisoner shall not be permitted to communicate with any outside person , or that person with him , without the leave of the Secretary of ORG .
Personal letters and visits
Rule CARDINAL

( CARDINAL) A prisoner shall not be entitled under this Rule to communicate with any person in connection with any legal or other business , or with any person other than a relative or friend , except with the leave of the Secretary of ORG .
Legal advisers
Rule CARDINAL

( CARDINAL ) The legal adviser of a prisoner in any legal proceedings , civil or criminal , to which the prisoner is a party shall be afforded reasonable facilities for interviewing him in connection with those proceedings , and may do so out of hearing but in the sight of an officer .
( CARDINAL ) A prisoner ’s legal adviser may , with the leave of the Secretary of ORG , interview the prisoner in connection with any other legal business in the sight and hearing of an officer . "
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG directed the prison governor to notify ORG reply to his petition of DATE as follows :

" The Secretary of ORG has fully considered your petition but is not prepared to grant your request for transfer , nor can he find grounds for taking any action in regard to the other matters raised in your petition . "

CARDINAL . Before the Commission , PERSON submitted CARDINAL complaints relating respectively to the stopping of his letters ( as mentioned above at paragraph CARDINAL ) and to the refusal of the Home Secretary to permit him to consult a solicitor . On DATE , the Commission declared the first complaint inadmissible , as all domestic remedies had not been exhausted , but accepted the second for consideration of the merits under Articles CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( article DATE , article CARDINAL) of the Convention .
CARDINAL . PERSON was released from prison on parole on DATE .
CARDINAL . In their report , the ORG expressed the opinion :
- unanimously , that LAW para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) guarantees a right of access to the courts ;

- unanimously , that in LAW CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) , whether read alone or together with other Articles of the LAW , there are no inherent limitations on the right of a convicted prisoner to institute proceedings and for this purpose to have unrestricted access to a lawyer ; and that consequently the restrictions imposed by the present practice of the GPE authorities are inconsistent with Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) ;
- by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , that Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article LAW ) is applicable to the facts of the present case ;

- that the same facts which constitute a violation of LAW para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) constitute also a violation of LAW article CARDINAL) ( by CARDINAL votes to one , as explained to the ORG by ORG on DATE ) .

The ORG furthermore expressed the opinion that the right of access to the courts guaranteed by Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) is not qualified by the requirement " within a reasonable time " . In the application bringing the case before ORG , the Government made objection to this opinion of the Commission but stated in their memorial that they no longer wished to argue the issue .
CARDINAL . The following final submissions were made to ORG at the oral hearing on DATE in the afternoon .
- for the Government :

" ORG respectfully submit to ORG that Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the LAW does not confer on the applicant a right of access to the courts , but confers only a right in any proceedings he may institute to a hearing that is fair and in accordance with the other requirements of the paragraph . The ORG submit that in consequence the refusal of ORG to allow the applicant in this case to consult a lawyer was not a violation of LAW ) . In the alternative , if the ORG finds that the rights conferred by LAW ) include in general a right of access to courts , then ORG submit that the right of access to the courts is not unlimited in the case of persons under detention , and that accordingly the imposing of a reasonable restraint on recourse to the courts by the applicant was permissible in the interest of prison order and discipline , and that the refusal of ORG to allow the applicant to consult a lawyer was within the degree of restraint permitted , and therefore did not constitute a violation of LAW .

ORG further submit that control over the applicant ’s correspondence while he was in prison was a necessary consequence of the deprivation of his liberty , and that the action of ORG was therefore not a violation of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article LAW ) , and that the action of ORG in any event fell within the exceptions provided by Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article LAW ) , since the restriction imposed was in accordance with law , and it was within the power of appreciation of the Government to judge that the restriction was necessary in a NORP society for the prevention of disorder or crime .

In the light of these submissions , Mr. President , I respectfully ask this honourable ORG , on behalf of ORG , to hold that ORG have not in this case committed a breach of LAW CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL) of ORG . "
- for the Commission :
" The questions to which the ORG is requested to reply are the following :
( CARDINAL ) Does Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of LAW secure to persons desiring to institute civil proceedings a right of access to the courts ?

( CARDINAL ) If Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) secures such a right of access , are there inherent limitations relating to this right , or its exercise , which apply to the facts of the present case ?

( CARDINAL ) Can a convicted prisoner who wishes to write to his lawyer in order to institute civil proceedings rely on the protection given in DATE ( article CARDINAL) of the LAW to respect for correspondence ?

( CARDINAL ) According to the answers given to the foregoing questions , do the facts of the present case disclose the existence of a violation of LAW CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL , article CARDINAL) of ORG ? "
